alerts.title: Permanent fire prohibition on Teewah Beach
alerts.description: A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.
alerts.details:
A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.

This permanent fire prohibition was implemented to reduce the risk of bushfires, protect critical habitat of native wildlife, enhance visitor safety from campfire related injuries and reduce rubbish from non-combustible materials being burnt.

Fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances can still be used in camping areas that meet the below requirements.

  • The appliance must use gas or manufactured fuel (heat beads, briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include timber or wood.
  • It must be used only for cooking and/or heating.
  • It must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation. 
  • It must not have the potential to generate airborne embers, or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels.
  • It must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use.
  • Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted.
  • All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the recreation area on your departure.

On the spot fines of $806 can be issued to people who light fires during a fire prohibition.

Campfires are permitted at Poverty Point camping area and at nearby Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area unless in accordance with all local directions for that area.

For details on the difference between a Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) total fire ban and a QPWS fire prohibition and approved cooking appliances visit the DES Camp fires and cooking web page.

QPWS thanks you for your cooperation while we implement this management change.

alerts.title: North West Island declaration of Special Activity Area (Sharks)
alerts.description: A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.
alerts.details:
A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

This applies to the area surrounding North West Island on North West Island Reef to reduce the risk of humans interacting with sharks. Within the special activity area shown on the map (https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/capricornia-cays/maps-resources)

You must not:

  • attract sharks by any means or methods to have a close interaction
  • process fish product
  • dump fish scraps
  • clean fish processing equipment.

Penalties may apply if you do any of these activities without prior permission or agreement under Section 132 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

alerts.title: Dingo (Wongari) Seasonal Information - Whelping Season
alerts.description: Limiting dingo-human interaction, particularly during wongari (dingo) whelping season, is critical to the welfare of pups. This is a particularly important time for pups to learn natural hunting and survival skills and to avoid habituation towards people.
alerts.details:
Limiting dingo-human interaction, particularly during wongari (dingo) whelping season, is critical to the welfare of pups. This is a particularly important time for pups to learn natural hunting and survival skills and to avoid habituation towards people.

Wongari (Dingo) whelping season means:

  • Wongari (Dingo) pups will venture out of their dens and explore their surroundings
  • Adult wongari (dingoes) will be teaching their young natural hunting and survival skills
  • Wongari (Dingoes) may be determined and aggressive in their search for food
  • Females will aggressively defend their young
  • Female wongari (dingoes) that are feeding young can lose condition and become naturally lean during this time

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to be dingo-safe! on K’gari. It is recommended that families with young children camp in fenced QPWS camping areas at Lake Boomanjin, Central Station, Dundubara and Waddy Point and eastern beach fenced areas (Wongai, One Tree Rocks, Cornwells, Eli), or at fenced private camping areas at Dilli Village or Cathedral Beach.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • Always stay close (within arm’s reach) of children and young teenagers.
  • Always walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Camp in fenced areas where possible.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Never feed dingoes.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

For further information about wongari (dingoes) on K’gari (Fraser Island) please visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Camper Hygiene
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) reminds campers of the need to maintain high personal hygiene standards whilst camping in the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) reminds campers of the need to maintain high personal hygiene standards whilst camping in the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.

QPWS would like to remind all visitors to maintain high personal hygiene, including washing hands frequently with soap and water, particularly after visiting the toilet, when preparing food and before eating and after visiting waste disposal and water point sites.

For the health and wellbeing of our park visitors and staff, and to limit the spread of illness visitors are recommended to:

  • Wash hands often with soap and water, especially before preparing food, eating and after going to the toilet (viral and bacterial stomach illnesses are not prevented with alcohol-based sanitisers).
  • Ensure all campers have a personal towel for hand drying.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with your elbow or a tissue.
  • Ensure your campsite is located away from other tents.
  • Where possible, bring your own portable toilet (mandatory for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas)
  • Keep your rubbish secure and dispose in bins provided or take home.
  • Stay at home if you or any members of your group are unwell.
  • Keep a personal supply of drinking and washing water during your stay. 

Check Park Alerts regularly for updates on current park conditions.

alerts.title: Portable toilets mandatory for Teewah Beach camping zones
alerts.description: All campers staying within the Teewah Beach camping zones 1 to 7 must bring and use a portable toilet for the duration of their stay. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required.
alerts.details:
All campers staying within the Teewah Beach camping zones 1 to 7 must bring and use a portable toilet for the duration of their stay. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required.

Portable toilets must have a sealed waste holding tank and must be transportable and suitable for emptying into a portable toilet waste disposal facility. Bag and open bucket style toilets are not permitted. 

Disposal waste facilities are available for use by campers at the following locations:

  • Second cutting, Noosa North Shore.
  • Freshwater day-use area, (beach camper service bay).
  • Clarkson Drive, Rainbow Beach.

Note: This is a permanent management change for Teewah Beach. 

It is an offence to camp at Teewah Beach camping area without a portable toilet, penalties apply.

alerts.title: George Point toilet removed due to erosion
alerts.description: George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.
alerts.details:
George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.

The camping area signage and infrastructure has been washed out and the toilet has been removed.

There is bush camping available nearby if needed by Thorsborne Trail hikers or sea kayakers. Space for camping is available under a large stand of trees approximately 150m to the northeast along the beach (prior to reaching the camping area when hiking from north to south). Please be aware there is no formal camping area and no toilet/pack rack. There is no boat-based camping available.

QPWS is currently reviewing options for the future of the site as part of the Thorsborne Trail Enhancement project.

alerts.title: Threatening dingo activity - Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba
alerts.description: Instances of threatening dingo behaviour have been reported at some locations including Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba.
alerts.details:
Instances of threatening dingo behaviour have been reported at some locations including Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba.

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to be dingo-safe! on Fraser Island.

Locations of threatening dingo behaviour:

  • Happy Valley to Cathedral Beach (including beach camping areas)
  • Eli Creek
  • Waddy Point to Ngkala Rocks (including beach camping areas)
  • Wathumba
  • Western beach camping areas

It is recommended that visitors be extra vigilant in these areas. Consider camping in fenced QPWS camping areas.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.
  • No food to lakeshores.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

 

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Bribie Islands northern breakaway section remains part of the recreation area
alerts.description: In early 2022, a new coastal bar was cut through Bribie Island 2kms from the northern end of Bribie Island Recreation Area, separating the park into two sections.
alerts.details:
In early 2022, a new coastal bar was cut through Bribie Island 2kms from the northern end of Bribie Island Recreation Area, separating the park into two sections.

This northern breakaway section of Bribie Island remains part of the Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area. While the national park boundary remains at the high tide mark, the recreation area boundary extends down to the mean low water mark and moves with the accretion and erosion of the sand. Newly formed sandbars and vegetated dunes at this northern breakaway section fall within the recreation area boundary.

Boaties and mainland residents are reminded that this northern breakaway section is not suitable for dog walking.

All national park and recreation area regulations continue to be enforceable including dogs, fires and camping being prohibited from this section of the recreation area.

Rangers will be patrolling this area and can issue fines for anyone caught breaching park rules.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

During this time barges, heli-lift activities and heavy plant machinery may be present at track access points at Tongue, Chance and Torres Herald Bays and other remote Whitsunday Island locations. alerts.title: Unstable sand cliffs and dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches
alerts.description: Exposed sand cliffs and sand dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches are unstable and can collapse without warning. Falling boulders and landslides are common in this dynamic coastal environment and can result in serious injury or death.
alerts.details:
Exposed sand cliffs and sand dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches are unstable and can collapse without warning. Falling boulders and landslides are common in this dynamic coastal environment and can result in serious injury or death.

For your safety and to avoid injuries:

  • Do not climb or dig into sand dunes or sand cliffs.
  • Avoid standing, sitting or parking near the base of the dunes.
  • Always stay well away from the base of sand dunes.
  • Supervise children at all times.

Beach travel is recommended two hours either side of low tide. Travelling three hours either side of high tide should be avoided.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Roadworks at Cunninghams Gap - temporary changes of walking tracks
alerts.description: Due to current and ongoing restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, walking tracks and visitor areas at the Cunninghams Gap section of Main Range National Park have been temporarily affected.
alerts.details:
Due to current and ongoing restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, walking tracks and visitor areas at the Cunninghams Gap section of Main Range National Park have been temporarily affected.

The following visitor areas have changed conditions:

  • All Cunningham Gap section walking tracks start from the West Gap Creek picnic area, via the Box Forest track. This includes Mount Cordeaux, Mount Mitchell, Bare Rock and the Rainforest circuit tracks. Walkers need to be aware of the extra 5km this will add to their intended walk. 
  • Access to The Crest carpark will be closed to all traffic from the Cunningham Highway.
  • Mount Mitchell track has been temporarily realigned and can be accessed from the western side of The Crest carpark via a temporary pedestrian crossing.
  • Visitors are encouraged to park at West Gap Creek picnic area 1.7km west from The Crest carpark.
  • Visitors are reminded that parking along the Cunningham Highway is prohibited. 

Road conditions and roadworks signage may vary depending on the stage of construction, and visitors are asked to follow all instructions and drive safely to road conditions.

For more information, please visit the Department of Transport and Main Roads website: Cunningham Highway (Ipswich – Warwick), 2020 Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements reconstruction works | Department of Transport and Main Roads (tmr.qld.gov.au).

Please monitor Queensland Traffic for updated information regarding road and traffic conditions.

For your safety please slow down and observe all directions and signs.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Partial closure: 1 of 4 Snapper Island campsites remain closed
alerts.description: The easternmost campsite of Snapper Island remains closed following damage from Cyclone Jasper in December 2023.
alerts.details:
The easternmost campsite of Snapper Island remains closed following damage from Cyclone Jasper in December 2023.

The other three campsites have been reopened and are available to book. The island has also been reopened for day use.

The island is open with caution; please be aware that there is still some debris around the sites and internal tracks, and noticeable cyclone damage to the island. Rangers have worked to ensure that visitor infrastructure is safe. The easternmost campsite will be reopened once additional works have been completed.

Please observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers and do not enter closed areas.

We apologise for any inconvenience.

If you have a camping booking and would like to request a camping credit or refund visit qld.gov.au/Camping

alerts.title: Extended baiting program for feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park, Dryander National Park, Dryander State Forest and Dryander Forest Reserve
alerts.description: The Department of Environment, Science and Innovation is undertaking a ground baiting program from 24 February 2024 to 24 February 2025. Manufactured baits will be used to control feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to each baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment, Science and Innovation website (www.des.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not allowed within protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs. For more information, please contact the department on 13 QGOV (13 74 68).

alerts.description: Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2024 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.
alerts.details:
Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2024 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.

Affected camp sites include:

  • Lime Pocket camping area - All sites
  • Mission Point camping area - Sites 1-6 
  • Gallagher Point camping area - All sites
  • Poverty Creek camping area - Sites 4 & 5

Please note heights are taken from the Brisbane Bar tide chart. This is due to the changes in water flow caused by the northern breakaway section of Bribie Island.

On waterfront sites campers should, where possible, consider placing tents and camping equipment back from the water’s edge to avoid any inundation from passing boats.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Russell Island camping area closed
alerts.description: Russell Island camping area will be closed until further notice while management authorities make decisions about the future suitability for recreational infrastructure in this area.
alerts.details:
Russell Island camping area will be closed until further notice while management authorities make decisions about the future suitability for recreational infrastructure in this area.

Erosion has significantly affected the northern beach of the low-lying sandy portion of Russell Island. This was exacerbated by Tropical Cyclone Jasper in December 2023. Erosion now threatens the camping area as well as the safe operation and longevity of the toilet block in its current location.

For this reason, Russell Island will be closed for camping indefinitely. The island is still open for day use.

Russell Island is a Commonwealth Island managed jointly by Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

alerts.details:
In conjunction with Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships (QPWS&P), the Noosa Council has upgraded the Cooroora Shared Trail 2 as part of the Noosa Trail master plan.

Upgrades completed include trail realignment, resurfacing and the moving of the trailhead to allow safer access and better parking options. 

The access point for the Cooroora Shared Trail 2, previously located at the School Street, has moved further west to Mountain Street. The Tuchekoi National Park map has been updated on the website to reflect these changes.

Please note dog walking is not permitted on the trails within Tuchekoi National Park. QPWS rangers do patrol the area and may issue on-the-spot fines for non-compliance.

alerts.details:
The Mt Kiangarow track and Burtons Well to Cherry Plain walk are closed, due to damage to the boot-washing station at the track entrance sustained during a severe weather event causing fallen trees.

Washdown stations help to prevent the spread of Phytophthora, a plant pathogen which causes disease in the Bunya pines. Tracks will re-open when the washdown stations are repaired. 

Alternative walking tracks from Westcott, Paradise carpark and Dandabah remain open to visitors. The Cherry Plain to Westcott track also remains open, although access to the Cherry Plain lookout is closed.

alerts.title: Portable toilets are mandatory for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) have introduced mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative had been introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) have introduced mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative had been introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.

From 01 June 2024, it is an offence to camp at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas without a portable toilet and penalties will apply. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required. Rangers will be on patrol to monitor compliance and educate campers about the benefits of using portable toilets.

Portable toilets must have a sealed waste holding tank and must be transportable and suitable for emptying into a portable toilet waste disposal facility. Bag and open bucket style toilets are not permitted. 

For your convenience, the Gympie Regional Council portable toilet waste disposal facility is located at Clarkson Drive, Rainbow Beach. Do not dispose of sanitary items, disposable nappies or toilet wipes into the toilet waste disposal facility as these items will block the system. Bag these items and take them home for disposal.

Do not empty your portable toilet waste into any toilets or general waste facilities in the recreation area as it creates a risk to human health and on-the-spot fines apply.

QPWS thanks you for your support and cooperation during this management change.

Note: This is a permanent management change for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas. 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Safety Advisory Notice: Coomera Falls circuit - High degree of caution required
alerts.description: Due to several compounding severe weather events and ongoing wet conditions the Coomera Falls circuit has sustained significant damage in parts, particularly in the southern section between the Coomera Falls Lookout and the Border track junction.
alerts.details:
Due to several compounding severe weather events and ongoing wet conditions the Coomera Falls circuit has sustained significant damage in parts, particularly in the southern section between the Coomera Falls Lookout and the Border track junction.

It is NOT RECOMMENDED for young children and/or anyone with physical limitations at present, until conditions improve.

  • The section between the Coomera Falls lookout and the junction with the Border track has significant damage to the track surface in parts, including a number of large fallen trees or obstructions, which can be challenging to negotiate, particularly in wet conditions, requiring a high level of experience and care.  Proceed with caution!
  • Creeks may also be swollen and fast-flowing, and rocks may be more slippery than usual.  Take extreme care when attempting creek crossings.  Remember, if it's flooded, forget it (even on walking tracks)!

Whilst the walking track has significant damage in parts, including minor diversions and challenging traverses, it remains within the Grade 4 walking track classification and expectations, in accordance with Australian Standards (AS2156.1-2001).

Please note that whilst the section of walking track from the Binna Burra trailhead to the Coomera Falls lookout is very muddy, it remains easily to moderately traversable.

Rangers are working to rectify and repair the damage.

Observe all signage, barriers, and directions from rangers, and do not enter the closed area.

Always remain on the designated walking track, wherever possible.  Your risk to personal safety increases significantly when straying from the designated walking track.

Please check Park Alerts as they are regularly updated regarding conditions on park.

alerts.title: On water signage in Great Sandy Marine Park
alerts.description: Great Sandy Marine Park users are advised not to rely on the presence of signage to inform them of their location within the various zones of the marine park. Marine Park zones are defined solely by GPS boundary locations, and users must refer to Schedule 1 and 2 of the Marine Parks (Great Sandy) Zoning Plan 2024 for precise boundary descriptions. There are reliable digital platforms which provide all-round coverage and information of all the zones and designated areas for users. eg. Electronic chart systems used on GPS chart plotters, electronic chart Apps used for navigation on smart devices, including Marine SQ App and the QLD Fisheries 2.0 App. Legacy advisory signs installed since 2006 are progressively phased out and updating of the Great Sandy Marine Park printed and web materials will continue to occur progressively.

There are reliable digital platforms which provide all-round coverage and information of all the zones and designated areas for users. eg. Electronic chart systems used on GPS chart plotters, electronic chart Apps used for navigation on smart devices, including Marine SQ App and the QLD Fisheries 2.0 App. Legacy advisory signs installed since 2006 are progressively phased out and updating of the Great Sandy Marine Park printed and web materials will continue to occur progressively.

alerts.title: Poison canisters washing up on Southeast Queensland beaches
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) is warning visitors of the potential dangers posed by toxic canisters washing up on Queensland beaches.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) is warning visitors of the potential dangers posed by toxic canisters washing up on Queensland beaches.

Since February 2012, emergency services have received reports from the public of small unlabelled canisters washing up on Australian beaches. QPWS continue to receive reports of these canisters washing up on beaches at K’gari, Mulgumpin (Moreton Island) and Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island).

The canisters contain a rat poison known as ‘aluminium phosphide’, a white to grey solid which is hazardous to humans.

When the canister is opened, the powder reacts with moisture in the air to release phosphine gas, which is also highly toxic to humans. The gas has a strong odour that can smell like garlic, rotting fish or urine, but it can quickly dull the sense of smell.

Exposure can cause symptoms such as headaches, nausea, vomiting, difficulty breathing, dizziness, tightness of the chest, diarrhoea, fluid in the lungs, liver/kidney damage, and in severe cases death.

The gas is also flammable and can spontaneously ignite causing burns or small explosions.

The canisters are silver in colour and approximately 22 centimetres tall. They have a tapered top with a screw in lid. Visit https://volunteerfirefighters.org.au/safety-advice-possible-toxic-canisters-washed-up-on-our-beaches for images of the canisters.

Canisters should not be moved or opened, and any sightings should be reported to emergency services on Triple Zero (000).

alerts.title: Planned burn season
alerts.description: Planned Burn season.
alerts.details:
Planned Burn season.

Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns from July- October when weather conditions are favourable.

Planned burns reduce the volume of fuels in forests and create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help to reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for native woodland regeneration.

Before any planned burn is undertaken, local stakeholders and booked campers will be informed.

Smoke may be seen coming from the Conway and Dryander National Park areas at times throughout the season. Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads and on the water, so it is important that motorists and vessel masters drive safely to the conditions.

Please observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers.

For more information, please contact QPWS&P on 13QGOV (13 74 68).

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Announcement: Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area pest management program for feral animals.
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service & Partnerships (QPWS&P) is continuing to protect critical habitat supporting threatened species on Bribie Island through its pest management program for feral animals.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service & Partnerships (QPWS&P) is continuing to protect critical habitat supporting threatened species on Bribie Island through its pest management program for feral animals.

Feral animals, such as pigs, foxes and horses pose a significant threat to our natural environment by disrupting ecosystems and negatively impacting native species. To address these environmental concerns, we actively engage in annual pest management programs to control their populations and minimise their impact, using a range of control techniques based on National Codes of Practice and Standard Operating Procedures.

Visitor safety is our main priority, which is why during quieter periods, we implement temporary closures of campsites and other sections of Park to conduct necessary pest control activities to meet the objectives of our approved pest strategy. Park visitors play a crucial role in this effort and are kindly reminded to securely store their food and rubbish. This simple action helps prevent attracting pests and exacerbating the issue, ensuring a safer and healthier environment for all park users.

Further information on the Department’s Management programs for Pest plants and animals can be found at - https://parks.desi.qld.gov.au/management/programs/pest-plants-animals

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

For your safety please avoid interaction with the wildlife.

alerts.title: Nearshore landslide Inskip Peninsula
alerts.description: Nearshore landslides are a common occurrence on the north facing beachfront of the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Nearshore landslides are a common occurrence on the north facing beachfront of the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.

Campers and pedestrians should exercise caution and check access conditions as landslides can occur anywhere at any time. This is part of ongoing natural coastal erosion. 

For your safety and to avoid injuries:

  • Keep well back from sand cliffs and waters’ edge as unstable beach sand may collapse without warning.
  • Avoid swimming or wading around the landslide.
  • Be aware that submerged objects and strong underwater currents may be present.
  • Nearby trees or branches may fall at any time.
  • Supervise children at all times on the beach.
  • Observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers, and do not enter closed areas.

Ensure compliance with any signage for your safety.

Report any unstable beach activity to 07 3087 8910.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Turtle Encounter tours 2024-2025 Season Mon Repos Conservation Park
alerts.description: Rangers are excited to announce the dates for the upcoming marine turtle nesting and hatching season at Mon Repos Conservation Park.
alerts.details:
Rangers are excited to announce the dates for the upcoming marine turtle nesting and hatching season at Mon Repos Conservation Park.

Turtle Encounter tour season will run from Saturday 9 November 2024 to Sunday 23 March 2025.

  • Nesting turtles can be viewed once tours commence in November until February, like any breeding season it can start off slowly and then reduce in numbers later in February.
  • Hatchling turtles can be viewed when they start to emerge - usually in early January - however it is low numbers of nests emerging at the start, building to a peak in February, and then slows down in late March.
  • A turtle’s arrival or hatchlings emerging can’t be predicted—some nights multiple turtle events happen early, sometimes only a few arrive at a time, and some turtle events happen after 11pm.

Bookings for Turtle Encounter Tours open on Monday 2 September 2024 at 12pm

It's important to know the below, before you book and read more information at Mon Repos Turtle Encounter tours :

  1. Tours are at night with Turtle Encounter tour groups comprises of up to 60 people.
  2. Moderate fitness level is required, you may have to walk 1.6km (return journey) at night in natural light or with limited light in some sections.
  3. You may have to stand on uneven, sandy surfaces for approximately two hours and traverse sandy surfaces, including short steep sandy sections on vegetated dunes, and boardwalk ramps.

alerts.title: Thorsborne Trail seasonal closure
alerts.description: The Thorsborne Trail will be closed from 1 January - 28 February due to the high risk of unsafe conditions over this period.
alerts.details:
The Thorsborne Trail will be closed from 1 January - 28 February due to the high risk of unsafe conditions over this period.

Seasonal conditions during these months bring extreme heat and regular heavy rainfall - hikers are often unable to cross creeks and are at the highest risk of heat-related injuries.

Extreme weather events are also more likely during these months.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

parks.name: Thorsborne Trail, Hinchinbrook Island National Park

alerts.title: Challenging summer hiking conditions
alerts.description: Hiking the Thorsborne Trail is considerably challenging during the summer months between October to March.
alerts.details:
Hiking the Thorsborne Trail is considerably challenging during the summer months between October to March.

Conditions can be extremely hot and humid at this time of year which increases the risk of heat related injuries. Water sources often dry up in the lead up to the wet season. When the wet season starts, high rainfall results in rapidly rising creeks making crossing dangerous. Extreme weather events are also more likely during the wet season. QPWS strongly recommends careful consideration of choosing to undertake the Thorsborne Trail hike during the summer months.

The Thorsborne Trail is closed seasonally from the start of January to the end of February due to the high risk of unsafe conditions over this period.

parks.name: Thorsborne Trail, Hinchinbrook Island National Park

alerts.title: Livestock seizure: Olkola National Park (CYPAL)
alerts.description: As of Sunday 15 September 2024, all stray stock located on Olkola National Park (CYPAL) have been seized by the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) under the authority of the Department of Environment, Science & Innovation (DESI). This is in accordance with section 154-E of the Nature Conservation Act 1992.
alerts.details:
As of Sunday 15 September 2024, all stray stock located on Olkola National Park (CYPAL) have been seized by the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) under the authority of the Department of Environment, Science & Innovation (DESI). This is in accordance with section 154-E of the Nature Conservation Act 1992.

It is an offence under section 154-O of the Nature Conservation Act 1992 for any person to tamper, interfere or remove any seized stock without authority.  The maximum penalty for an offence against this section is $16,100 (100 penalty units).

Claims are to be addressed to:

Regional Director, Northern Region
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service
DESI

email: qpws.cattle@des.qld.gov.au or by mail: PO Box 2066 Cairns QLD 4870

do not approach wongari at any time.

alerts.details:

Keep a respectful distance from areas where fish are visible.

Stay safe and enjoy your visit!

The camping area is heavily booked from Friday 20 September 2024 to Sunday 22 September 2024, and space usually available for camping is currently underwater.
alerts.details:
Higher than expected water levels of Tinaroo Dam have significantly reduced the amount of available space for camping at Kauri Creek camping area. The camping area is heavily booked from Friday 20 September 2024 to Sunday 22 September 2024, and space usually available for camping is currently underwater.

If you choose to continue with your camping booking, we ask that you are respectful of the limited space and of other campers.

In particular, please do not put up day-use gazebos. 

Should you wish to camp with more space, please consider changing your booking to Fong-On Bay camping area.

If you are no longer planning to camp at this time, please cancel or modify your booking.

Campers with bookings will receive an email with instructions on how to seek a refund.

alerts.title: Pest animal control
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service will be conducting pest activity control activities throughout Kroombit Tops National Park (KTNP) Commencing 28th October 2024 extending through to the 29th of November 2024.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service will be conducting pest activity control activities throughout Kroombit Tops National Park (KTNP) Commencing 28th October 2024 extending through to the 29th of November 2024.

The pest activities to be carried out across KTNP is to reduce the degradation on habitat and maximise the chances of long-term recovery of populations of identified threatened species endemic to the area and associated vegetation groups. This includes the Kroombit Tops Tinkerfrog, Kroombit Tops Tree Frog, Silver headed Antechinus and Monteiths spiny crayfish.

The control activities include a focus on the of public  safety and visitor experiance within  KTNP.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Refunds can be applied for via your online account at qld.gov.au/camping.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

The park will reopen when conditions are considered safe.

alerts.title: Conway National Park, Dryander National Park, Dryander State Forest and Dryander Forest Reserve feral animal management program
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships (QPWS&P) is undertaking an aerial baiting program on 3October 2024. Sodium Fluoroacetate (1080) meat baits will be used to control feral pigs on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). A licensed operator will distribute the baits by helicopter. These baits will not be collected. Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to the baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment and Science website (www.des.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not permitted within the protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the 1080 baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs.

alerts.title: Temporary partial closure - Coochin Hills section
alerts.description: A track within the Coochin Hills section, Glass House Mountains National Park, is temporarily closed due to phytophthora being detected in nearby National Parks.
alerts.details:
A track within the Coochin Hills section, Glass House Mountains National Park, is temporarily closed due to phytophthora being detected in nearby National Parks.

Plant species vulnerable to phytophthora are at risk.  Phytophthora is a soil-borne organism that kills key species of native plants and fruit trees. The pathogen is spread through the transmission of infected soil, commonly on footwear.

Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service is working with Biosecurity Queensland to prevent the spread of the disease.

Please help stop the spread into the park by not entering the closed section of Coochin Hills.

 

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

As a result, smoke may be seen in the area.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct planned burning activities (weather permitting) within Girringun National Park and Kirrama National Park from Tuesday 8 October to Friday 18 October 2024 (dates inclusive) as part of the annual hazard reduction/ conservation management program. As a result, smoke may be seen in the area.

The aim of this burn is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent bushfires and provide favourable conditions for natural regeneration.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important for that motorists drive safely and to the conditions

Fore more information, please call the Princess Hills QPWS office on (07) 4097 1448.

alerts.title: Drive with care during marine turtle nesting season
alerts.description: From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way from nest to ocean for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to nesting marine turtles.
alerts.details:
From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way from nest to ocean for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to nesting marine turtles.

When driving on the beach:

  • Plan to travel at 2 hours either side of low tide. Keep to the hard sand well below the high tide line to avoid making wheel ruts that create barriers to hatchling movement down the beach.
  • Avoid driving on the beach at night. This is when turtles will lay their eggs, and hatchlings are most likely to be emerging. Exercise caution and look out for turtles and turtle hatchlings when traversing on the beach.
  • If turtles are making their way across the beach - slow down, stop and wait for the turtles to reach the ocean or the dunes. On-the-spot fines apply to visitors disturbing turtle hatchlings or turtle nests.
  • Driving over vegetated dunes is dangerous and prohibited. It is damaging to the environment and can impact turtle nests, on-the-spot fines apply.

‘Cut the glow to help turtles go’. Artificial lights can affect a turtle’s ability to see the natural horizon over the ocean. Hatchlings can become disoriented, veer from their natural path and head towards the artificial light. When camping during the nesting season you can help cut the glow of lights affecting beaches by switching off unnecessary lights on the beach after 7.30pm.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers.

To report marine animal strandings (of sick, injured or dead turtles, dolphin, dugongs or whales) call 1300 130 372.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.
